TEXT: CARDINAL . NORP The applicant , Mr PERSON , is a NORP national who was born in DATE and lives in PERSON . The Government of GPE ( “ the Government ” ) were represented by their Agent , PERSON .
CARDINAL . NORP The facts of the case , as submitted by the parties , may be summarised as follows .

CARDINAL . NORP The applicant is a practising lawyer . By CARDINAL decisions given on DATE and DATE , ORG appointed him to represent a claimant in CARDINAL sets of constitutional proceedings brought under LAW and concerning an alleged breach of the claimant ’s rights under LAW and its constitutional equivalent . The appointment was made in the context of the claimant ’s request for legal aid . In the decisions , reference was made to section CARDINALa of LAW DATE and to Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure . They specified that the applicant had been chosen as his office was in the town where the claimant was detained .
CARDINAL . NORP In written submissions to ORG submitted on DATE and DATE , the president of the ordinary court concerned argued that there had been no breach of the claimant ’s rights .
CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE the claimant informed ORG that he insisted on an examination of his case at an oral hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE and DATE ORG declared admissible the claimant ’s complaints under LAW and rejected the remaining claims . On the last - mentioned date it joined the CARDINAL cases , to the extent that they had been declared admissible .

CARDINAL . NORP The president of the district court involved excused himself from the hearing scheduled for DATE . He cited a heavy workload and also the wish to avoid additional costs . He agreed to the hearing being held in the absence of any representative of his court . The applicant was not informed of that communication prior to the hearing .
CARDINAL . On DATE the applicant met his client , at the latter ’s request , in order to complete the file and prepare the submissions which were to be made at the hearing .

CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG heard the applicant and his client . The applicant submitted documentary evidence and arguments in support of the claimant ’s complaints . He also specified the claim in respect of his costs . It totalled CARDINAL NORP korunas ( SKK ) . That sum included SKK CARDINAL,CARDINAL in respect of the applicant ’s representation of the claimant at the hearing before ORG and time and costs relating to the applicant ’s journey to PERSON for the purpose of the hearing . The individual items claimed were based on the relevant provisions of Regulation CARDINAL/CARDINAL governing the payment of fees and costs to lawyers .

CARDINAL . By a judgment of CARDINAL DATE ORG found that LAW had been breached on CARDINAL occasions due to the fact that : ( i ) an ordinary court had not displayed due diligence in examining applications for release lodged by the applicant ’s client ; and ( ii ) a different court had failed to comply with the requirement of equality of arms when extending the claimant ’s detention .
CARDINAL . ORG ordered , inter alia , that FAC should be paid to the applicant for the costs of the claimant ’s representation . The relevant part of its decision reads :

“ ORG , with regard to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of LAW DATE , considers ... it justified to make an award of SKK CARDINAL,CARDINAL in respect of the costs of the claimant ’s legal representation ... [ It does not ] grant the other costs claimed by the plaintiff ’s representative , including the costs related to participation at the hearing held on DATE , the time of the return journey from PERSON to PERSON , and travel and subsistence costs , as it does not consider them to have been necessarily incurred , as neither the representative nor the claimant put forward any facts in the course of the hearing which were unknown to ORG on the basis of the claimant ’s complaint and the files at its disposal . ”

CARDINAL . The judgment specified that ORG had not considered documentary evidence which the applicant had submitted on behalf of his client in the course of the oral hearing , as that evidence had not concerned the subject - matter of the proceedings as determined by the decisions on the admissibility of the claimant ’s complaints .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the LAW guarantees to everyone the right to legal assistance in proceedings before courts , ORG authorities or public administration bodies under the conditions specified by law .
CARDINAL . Proceedings before ORG are governed by LAW ( “ the DATE LAW ) .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act , a person who wishes to bring proceedings before ORG has to submit for a mandate in favour of the lawyer representing him or her in the proceedings unless the DATE Act provides otherwise .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act , an oral hearing shall be held in proceedings concerning , inter alia , natural or legal ORG complaints brought under LAW . ORG may refrain from holding an oral hearing , subject to the parties’ agreement , where it can not be expected that relevant new information will be obtained thereby ( subsection CARDINAL of section CARDINAL ) . LAW ) of the DATE LAW and their representatives to attend oral hearings .

CARDINAL . Pursuant to section CARDINAL(a ) of the DATE Act , unless the DATE LAW provides otherwise or unless it is excluded by the nature of the matter , the provisions of LAW and of LAW are to be used by analogy in proceedings before ORG .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) of the DATE LAW provides that parties to proceedings before ORG have to bear their costs and expenses . LAW CARDINAL entitles ORG , where justified and in accordance with the outcome of the proceedings , to order a party to fully or partially reimburse the costs and expenses of the other party .

CARDINAL . DATE provides that courts should appoint a representative to a party to the proceedings , at the latter ’s request , provided that he or she meets the requirements for waiver of court fees and that such an appointment is necessary for the protection of the party ’s interests .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides , inter alia , that courts may grant a party ’s request for waiver of court fees where it is justified by the situation of the party and provided that the claim at issue is neither frivolous nor clearly devoid of any prospect of success .
CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL provides that where a lawyer was appointed to represent a party to proceedings , the ORG shall pay that lawyer ’s fees and reimburse his or her costs .

CARDINAL . Article CARDINAL § CARDINAL authorises courts to grant to a party who was fully successful in an action the reimbursement of the costs which were necessary for the effective exercise or protection of his or her rights vis - à - vis the unsuccessful party .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ) obliges lawyers to protect and pursue the rights and interests of their clients and to abide by the latter ’s instructions . Such instructions do not bind lawyers where they run contrary to generally binding legal rules . LAW of CARDINAL obliges lawyers to diligently use all legal means which they consider beneficial for their client . At the same time , lawyers should respect the principles of efficiency and economy while providing legal services .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL(CARDINAL ) provides that , without prejudice to section DATE , a lawyer is entitled to refuse to provide legal services unless he has been appointed under special rules , such as ORG DATE and CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL enumerates situations in which a lawyer is obliged to refuse to provide legal services . Thus , under point ( e ) , a lawyer has to refuse to provide legal services where he or she is unable , because of heavy workload or long - term absence , to duly protect the rights and interests of the client .
CARDINAL . Pursuant to section DATE , when a lawyer has been appointed under the legal aid scheme to assist a client , the remuneration for his legal services is to be paid by the ORG .

CARDINAL . Under section CARDINAL ) , a breach of an obligation under LAW DATE or an internal regulation of ORG attributable to a lawyer is qualified as a disciplinary offence . The sanctions for such offences are listed in subsection CARDINAL of section CARDINAL . They include a written warning , public reprimand , a fine , suspending the right to practice as a lawyer for a period from DATE and being struck off from the roll .

CARDINAL . With reference to section CARDINALa of LAW , taken in conjunction with Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL § CARDINAL of the Code of Civil Procedure , ORG has held that it may appoint a lawyer to represent a natural or legal person , at that person ’s request , provided that this is justified by the claimant ’s situation and that the case is not clearly devoid of any prospect of success .

CARDINAL . In judgment II . ÚS CARDINAL/CARDINAL of DATE ORG ruled that the right to reimbursement of costs which were properly incurred is a part of the fundamental right to legal assistance . However , it did not find a breach of that provision in a situation where the ordinary court involved , while applying LAW , had made no award in respect of costs . ORG held that the law provided for discretion in the assessment of whether the costs claimed were necessarily incurred . It concluded that the very essence of the claimant ’s right under LAW had not been affected .

CARDINAL . In judgment II . ÚS QUANTITY of DATE ORG found a breach of a person ’s right to a hearing within a reasonable time . That person was represented by the present applicant . ORG ordered the reimbursement of the applicant ’s fees and costs . The sum awarded also took into account the claimant ’s representation at the hearing held before FAC and time and costs relating to the applicant ’s journey to the seat of ORG for the hearing .

CARDINAL . In accordance with ORG practice ( for example , decision CARDINAL Obo CARDINAL of DATE ) , courts should assess whether costs incurred are reasonable . They should grant reimbursement of expenses which were necessary for the exercise or protection of a party ’s right .
